pageProps.body:
Evaluating Surface Integrals

Generalizing the line integral

Since we're studying all these different types of integrals, and each one is a generalization or specification or manifestation or personification of the last, it's occasionally useful to understand exactly how they're all connected - and what parts they're generalizing off of one another.

A surface integral is a generalization of two types of integrals: an area integral, whose idea of integrating along infinitesimal areas dAdAdA is generalized to two-dimensional surfaces in three dimensions, rather than in the two-dimensional plane, and a line integral, whose idea of taking directional slices along a curve is generalized to taking directional slices along a surface.

Let's take a look at how each of these generalizations operate.

Areas along a parametric surface

For an area integral, the area differential dA=dx dydA = dx\ dydA=dx dy represented the process of splitting a region into infinitesimally small rectangular areas, each with length dxdxdx and with dydydy. For a surface integral over a parametric surface S=x(u,v)S = \mathbf{x}(u,v)S=x(u,v), we deal not with rectangular areas, but with surface areas along the uuu- and vvv-directions - much like how, over a curve CCC, we deal with arc length dsdsds instead of the differential dxdxdx along a straight line.

There is zero guarantee that uuu and vvv are orthogonal; given a small increment along the uuu-axis δu\delta uδu and along the vvv-axis δv\delta vδv, we can only guarantee that, at infinitesimal scales, the infinite sum of the parallelograms formed by the vector

x(u+δu,v)−x(u,v)\mathbf{x}(u+\delta u, v) - \mathbf{x}(u, v)x(u+δu,v)−x(u,v)

and the vector

x(u,v+δv)−x(u,v)\mathbf{x}(u, v+\delta v) - \mathbf{x}(u,v)x(u,v+δv)−x(u,v)

can approximate the surface area of SSS. The above two expressions look exactly like partial derivatives:

x(u+δu,v)−x(u,v)=∂x∂u δu\mathbf{x}(u+\delta u, v) - \mathbf{x}(u, v) = \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \ \delta ux(u+δu,v)−x(u,v)=∂u∂x​ δu

and, correspondingly,

x(u,v+δv)−x(u,v)=∂x∂v δv.\mathbf{x}(u, v+\delta v) - \mathbf{x}(u, v) = \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v} \ \delta v.x(u,v+δv)−x(u,v)=∂v∂x​ δv.

The area of the parallelogram formed by two vectors is the magnitude of the cross-product of the two vectors, and thus our expression for the surface area differential dSdSdS is

∣∂x∂u δu×∂x∂v δv∣| \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \ \delta u \times \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v} \ \delta v|∣∂u∂x​ δu×∂v∂x​ δv∣

where δu\delta uδu and δv\delta vδv are scalars, and thus the above expression equals

dS=∣∂x∂u×∂x∂v∣ du dvdS = |\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \times \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v}|\ du\ dvdS=∣∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​∣ du dv

where the cross product equals our expression for the normal vector to the surface!

Definition. Define the scalar area differential for a surface SSS parameterized as x(u,v)\mathbf{x}(u,v)x(u,v) as

dS=∣∂x∂u×∂x∂v∣ du dvdS = |\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \times \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v}|\ du\ dvdS=∣∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​∣ du dv

as opposed to the vector area differential (encountered later).

Reparameterization invariance

Like the uniqueness of the arc length parameterization for line integrals, the above definition for the surface area differential is independent of the parameterization (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) chosen for a surface.

Suppose we wish to re-parameterize the surface via alternative parameters uˉ,vˉ\bar{u}, \bar{v}uˉ,vˉ, assuming that each can be expressed as (scalar) functions of uuu and vvv (and vice versa). By the chain rule, we have

∂x∂uˉ=∂x∂u∂u∂uˉ+∂x∂v∂v∂uˉ\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \bar{u}} = \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \frac{\partial u}{\partial \bar{u}} + \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v} \frac{\partial v}{\partial \bar{u}}∂uˉ∂x​=∂u∂x​∂uˉ∂u​+∂v∂x​∂uˉ∂v​

and

∂x∂vˉ=∂x∂u∂u∂vˉ+∂x∂v∂v∂vˉ\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \bar{v}} = \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \frac{\partial u}{\partial \bar{v}} + \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v} \frac{\partial v}{\partial \bar{v}}∂vˉ∂x​=∂u∂x​∂vˉ∂u​+∂v∂x​∂vˉ∂v​

leading to

∣∂x∂uˉ×∂x∂vˉ∣=(∂x∂u∂u∂uˉ+∂x∂v∂v∂uˉ)×(∂x∂u∂u∂vˉ+∂x∂v∂v∂vˉ)=0+(∂u∂uˉ∂v∂vˉ)∣∂x∂u×∂x∂v∣−(∂u∂vˉ∂v∂uˉ) ∣∂x∂u×∂x∂v∣+0=∂(u,v)∂(uˉ,vˉ)∣∂x∂u×∂x∂v∣=du dvduˉ dvˉ ∣∂x∂u×∂x∂v∣\begin{aligned} |\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \bar{u}} \times \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \bar{v}}| &= (\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \frac{\partial u}{\partial \bar{u}} + \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v} \frac{\partial v}{\partial \bar{u}}) \times (\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \frac{\partial u}{\partial \bar{v}} + \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v} \frac{\partial v}{\partial \bar{v}}) \\ &= 0 + (\frac{\partial u}{\partial \bar{u}} \frac{\partial v}{\partial \bar{v}})|\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial u}\times \frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial v}| - (\frac{\partial u}{\partial \bar{v}} \frac{\partial v}{\partial \bar{u}})\ |\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial u}\times \frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial v}| + 0 \\ &= \frac{\partial(u,v)}{\partial(\bar{u},\bar{v})}|\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial u}\times \frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial v}| \\ &= \frac{du\ dv}{d\bar{u}\ d\bar{v}}\ |\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial u}\times \frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial v}| \end{aligned}∣∂uˉ∂x​×∂vˉ∂x​∣​=(∂u∂x​∂uˉ∂u​+∂v∂x​∂uˉ∂v​)×(∂u∂x​∂vˉ∂u​+∂v∂x​∂vˉ∂v​)=0+(∂uˉ∂u​∂vˉ∂v​)∣∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​∣−(∂vˉ∂u​∂uˉ∂v​) ∣∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​∣+0=∂(uˉ,vˉ)∂(u,v)​∣∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​∣=duˉ dvˉdu dv​ ∣∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​∣​

where the last two lines are due to the Jacobian, leading to

∣∂x∂uˉ×∂x∂vˉ∣ duˉ dvˉ=∣∂x∂u×∂x∂v∣ du dv.|\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \bar{u}} \times \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \bar{v}}|\ d\bar{u}\ d\bar{v} = |\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial u}\times \frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial v}|\ du\ dv.∣∂uˉ∂x​×∂vˉ∂x​∣ duˉ dvˉ=∣∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​∣ du dv.

Scalar fields

Definition. For a scalar field ϕ(x)\phi(\mathbf{x})ϕ(x) and a parameterized surface S=x(u,v)S = \mathbf{x}(u,v)S=x(u,v) defined over a region D={(u,v):ua<u<ub, va<v<vb}D = \{(u,v): u_a < u < u_b,\ v_a < v < v_b\}D={(u,v):ua​<u<ub​, va​<v<vb​}, define the scalar surface integral as the area integral

∫vavb∫uaubϕ(x(u,v)) ∣∂x∂u×∂x∂v∣ du dv\int_{v_a}^{v_b} \int_{u_a}^{u_b} \phi(\mathbf{x}(u,v))\ |\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial u} \times \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v}|\ du\ dv∫va​vb​​∫ua​ub​​ϕ(x(u,v)) ∣∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​∣ du dv

regardless of the parameterization (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) considered.

Note that taking ϕ=1\phi = 1ϕ=1 simply gives the surface area of the surface.

Example. Find the surface area of a sphere of radius aaa.

I sure love it when calculus textbooks demonstrate the unadulterated power of calculus by overcomplicating statements in my fifth-grade textbook and irrevocably lifting the veil of innocence from my untarnished childhood forever.

Apply a parameterization in, big surprise, spherical coordinates:

x(θ,ϕ)=(x,y,z)=[asin⁡ϕcos⁡θasin⁡ϕsin⁡θacos⁡ϕ], 0≤ϕ≤π, 0≤θ≤2π,\mathbf{x(\theta, \phi)} = (x,y,z) = \begin{bmatrix} a\sin \phi \cos \theta \\ a \sin \phi \sin \theta\\ a \cos \phi \end{bmatrix},\ 0 \leq \phi \leq \pi,\ 0 \leq \theta \leq 2\pi,x(θ,ϕ)=(x,y,z)=⎣⎡​asinϕcosθasinϕsinθacosϕ​⎦⎤​, 0≤ϕ≤π, 0≤θ≤2π,

leading to

dS=∣∂x∂θ×∂x∂ϕ∣=∣[−asin⁡ϕsin⁡θasin⁡ϕcos⁡θ0]×[acos⁡ϕcos⁡θacos⁡ϕsin⁡θ−asin⁡ϕ]∣=a2sin⁡ϕ dθ dϕdS = |\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}}{\partial \theta} \times \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \phi}| = |\begin{bmatrix} -a\sin\phi\sin\theta \\ a\sin\phi\cos\theta \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\times \begin{bmatrix} a\cos\phi\cos\theta \\ a\cos\phi\sin\theta \\ -a\sin\phi \end{bmatrix}| = a^2\sin \phi\ d\theta\ d\phidS=∣∂θ∂x​×∂ϕ∂x​∣=∣⎣⎡​−asinϕsinθasinϕcosθ0​⎦⎤​×⎣⎡​acosϕcosθacosϕsinθ−asinϕ​⎦⎤​∣=a2sinϕ dθ dϕ

(Source: trust me bro/sis/gender-neutral-term-of-vitriolic-affection.)

The surface integral that leads to the surface area can be formulated as

∫0π∫02πa2sin⁡ϕ dθ dϕ=2πa2∫0πsin⁡ϕ dϕ=4πa2\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{\pi} \int_{0}^{2\pi}a^2\sin\phi\ d\theta\ d\phi \\ = 2\pi a^2 \int_{0}^{\pi}\sin\phi\ d\phi \\ = 4\pi a^2 \end{aligned}∫0π​∫02π​a2sinϕ dθ dϕ=2πa2∫0π​sinϕ dϕ=4πa2​

I can't believe it took these calculus nerds two semesters in Cambridge to figure out what I knew ever since fourth grade.

Vector fields

As promised, we now define the vector-valued analogue to the scalar area differential dSdSdS:

Definition. Define the vector area differential, denoted dSd\mathbf{S}dS, for a surface SSS parameterized by x(u,v)\mathbf{x}(u,v)x(u,v) as

dS=(∂x∂u×∂x∂v) du dvd\mathbf{S} = (\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial u}\times \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial v})\ du\ dvdS=(∂u∂x​×∂v∂x​) du dv

with the cross-product term no longer behind bars, having served its sentence for first-degree murder of kxk\mathbf{x}kx in the presence of x\mathbf{x}x. In contrast to dSdSdS, dSd\mathbf{S}dS is a vector with direction pointing in the normal to the surface and magnitude dSdSdS; it thus encodes both surface area and surface direction within it, and that fact allows us to calculate

Definition. Flux. Suppose that the vector field F(x)\mathbf{F(x)}F(x) denotes the velocity field of a fluid, i.e. its direction and magnitude of flow at every point; we define the flux of the fluid about a surface SSS as the amount of fluid crossing the surface SSS per unit time.

This definition of flux is made calculable through the surface integral by two relevant facts:

  1. The direction pointing out of the surface at a point is given by dSd\mathbf{S}dS (pointing in the direction of the normal vector to the surface);
  2. The flow of a fluid F\mathbf{F}F in the direction n\mathbf{n}n is given by the dot product F⋅n\mathbf{F\cdot n}F⋅n.

All of this leads to the following formulation for flux, given a surface SSS, a velocity field F(x)\mathbf{F(x)}F(x), and a region DDD in the u−vu-vu−v plane over which the surface lies:

∫DF⋅dS\int_D \mathbf{F\cdot dS}∫D​F⋅dS

We can, of course, speak of flux even if the underlying vector field F\mathbf{F}F does not describe fluid flow; electric flux and magnetic flux - the electric and magnetic fields passing through a surface, respectively - are good examples in this vein.
